      87. 87
        Nahm, S.; Weinreb, S. M. N-Methoxy-N-methylamides as effective acylating agents Tetrahedron Lett. 1981, 22, 3815– 3818
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        87
        N-Methoxy-N-methylamides as effective acylating agents
        Nahm, Steven; Weinreb, Steven M.
        Tetrahedron Letters (1981), 22 (39), 3815-18CODEN: TELEAY; ISSN:0040-4039.
        N-Methoxy-N-methylamides couple readily with both Grignard and organolithium reagents in THF to give ketones; tertiary alcs. were not formed even in the presence of large excesses of the organometallic compd. E.g., treatment of Me(CH2)16CONMeOMe (I), prepd. from Me(CH2)16COCl and HNMeOMe.HCl (pyridine/CHCl3, room temp., 1 h), with 2 equiv MeMgBr (THF, 0°, 1 h) gave 94% Me(CH2)16COMe. Hydride redn. of the N-methoxy-N-methylamides gave the corresponding aldehydes, together with small amts. of the primary alc. E.g., I with excess LiAlH4 (THF, -78°, 5 min) gave 50% Me(CH2)16CHO and 25% Me(CH2)17OH.

      95. 95
        Natale, N. R.; Hutchins, R. O. An efficient, general synthesis of spiroalkanes and related derivatives Org. Prep. Proced. Int. 1977, 9, 103– 108
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        95
        An efficient, general synthesis of spiroalkenes and related derivatives
        Natale, Nicholas R.; Hutchins, Robert O.
        Organic Preparations and Procedures International (1977), 9 (3-4-5), 103-8CODEN: OPPIAK; ISSN:0030-4948.
        Enamines I [Z = CH2, CH2CH2, (CH2)4, CH:CH] were converted to spiroalkenes II. I were heated with MeCOCH:CH2, HOAc and NaOAc were added, and the mixts. were heated to give spiroalkenones III. III were converted to their tosylhydrazones and the latter were treated with catechol borane to give the II.

      103. 103
        Grimont, J.; Le Goff, F.; Bourquin, G.; Silva, J. Quality Assessment and Concentration Determination of Actelion’s Compound Solutions by Automated LCMS and Quantitative NMR. Presented at MipTec: The Leading European Event for Drug Discovery, Basel, Switzerland, Sep 20–24, 2010.

      104. 104
        Seglen, P. O.; Fosså, J. Attachment of rat hepatocytes in vitro to substrata of serum protein collagen, or concanavalin A Exp. Cell Res. 1978, 116, 199– 206
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        104
        Attachment of rat hepatocytes in vitro to substrata of serum protein, collagen, or concanavalin A
        Seglen, Per O.; Fossa, Jon
        Experimental Cell Research (1978), 116 (1), 199-206CODEN: ECREAL; ISSN:0014-4827.
        Isolated rat hepatocytes attached to, and spread on, the surface of polystyrene tissue culture dishes in the presence of serum. The attachment was essentially complete in 30 min at 37°, whereas no attachment occurred at 0°. Dead (trypan blue-stainable) cells did not attach; hence, the plating efficiency (percentage of cells attaching) was close to the percentage of intact cells in the hepatocyte suspension. Attachment in the presence of serum was relatively independent of pH, but required divalent cations. Mg2+ stimulated attachment more effectively than Ca2+, and a combination of both cations gave maximal attachment. Cells did not attach readily to untreated dishes in the absence of serum, but attached to and spread on dishes precoated with adsorbed serum protein, concanavalin A (ConA), or a film of collagen. The attachment-promoting activity in serum was destroyed by acid treatment, by heating to 70°, and by protease treatment. It is, therefore, probably a protein, which, like collagen and ConA, can bind to receptors hepatocyte surface.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE1MXitVSqtw%253D%253D&md5=f23fe77ed9d9f43188571b536fe8f725
      105. 105
        Obach, R. S. The prediction of human clearance from hepatic microsomal metabolism data Curr. Opin. Drug Discovery Dev. 2001, 4, 36– 44
        [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        105
        The prediction of human clearance from hepatic microsomal metabolism data
        Obach, R. Scott
        Current Opinion in Drug Discovery & Development (2001), 4 (1), 36-44CODEN: CODDFF; ISSN:1367-6733. (PharmaPress Ltd.)
        A review with 42 refs. Human liver microsomal intrinsic clearance has become a commonly measured parameter during drug discovery, and such data are used to design compds. predicted to possess optimal drug disposition characteristics. Liver microsomal intrinsic clearance values can be scaled and used to predict hepatic clearance in humans. Clearance, when combined with the vol. of distribution, dets. the half-life of a drug. Hepatic clearance, when combined with absorption, dets. the oral bioavailability of a drug. Half-life and oral bioavailability are key determinants of the dosing regimen, ie, size of dose and frequency of administration. Thus, the accurate prediction of human clearance is important in the selection of new compds. for progression into development, as new drugs on the market must not only be efficacious and safe, but must also be convenient to use for patients and physicians. Over the past decade, exploring methods whereby human clearance can be predicted from in vitro data has been an area of active research in drug metab. science. Human liver microsomes have been a key tool in this research. This in vitro system possesses many of the major drug metabolizing enzymes and is thus applicable to a wide variety of compds. This review describes the theor. and practical aspects of predicting clearance from human liver microsomal intrinsic clearance data, a summary of advantages and shortcomings of this in vitro system, a synopsis of recent applications of human liver microsomal intrinsic clearance data in clearance predictions, and a discussion of potential future directions for this field.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXlvFOlsQ%253D%253D&md5=421bc7764c3d7f501b69aa97996d1db9
      106. 106
        Armarego, W. L. F.; Chai, C. L. L. Purification of Laboratory Chemicals, 6th ed.; Elsevier: Amsterdam, 2009.
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      107. 107
        Buxbaum, E. Biophysical Chemistry of Proteins: An Introduction to Laboratory Methods; Springer: New York, 2011.
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
